qas.question: What are the newer micro-USB receptacles designed for?

answers.text: a minimum rated lifetime of 10,000 cycles of insertion

qas.question: What is the minimum rated lifetime for the standard USB receptacle?
After a leaf-spring was moved from jack to the plug, the most stressed part was found where?

answers.text: on the cable side of the connection

qas.question: Why was the change made for the USB device?

answers.text: so that the connector on the less expensive cable would bear the most wear

context: The newer micro-USB receptacles are designed for <a0_0>a minimum rated lifetime of 10,000 cycles of insertion<a0_0/> and removal between the receptacle and plug, compared to <a1_0>1,500<a1_0/> for the standard USB and 5,000 for the mini-USB receptacle. Features intended to accomplish include, a locking device was added and the leaf-spring was moved from the jack to the plug, so that the most-stressed part is <a2_0>on the cable side of the connection<a2_0/>. This change was made <a3_0>so that the connector on the less expensive cable would bear the most wear<a3_0/> instead of the more expensive micro-USB device. However the idea that these changes did in fact make the connector more durable in real world use has been widely disputed, with many contending that they are in fact, much less durable.
